segments.text: Should there be one central agency to direct oceanography in this country?
No, I don't think so.
I think it always seems very tidy to have it that way.
And it is something that the congressmen always seem to want, something they can understand.
It's a wiring program.
They'd like a simple wiring program where they can see everything nice and neat and tidy.
But I think the strength of the American system is, well, it's based on its performance.
I mean, we're way, way ahead of the Russians, for example, in oceanography, way ahead of the rest of the world.
And we do more oceanography in all of Western Europe together.
The Russians, the congressmen and some people are wanting to claim the Russians are ahead of us.
And this is mainly a gambit, I guess, to get more funding.
And they quote ship tonnages and things like that.
But the Russian works are simply, although it's very tidy, I'm trying to point out that they have a very, very
You can understand their wiring diagram very well.
You can see Venero and the various agencies.
It's very nicely organized.
But it just doesn't run.
Because the strength of our system is that it is so loose and so loosely structured
We have industrial groups.
We have university groups.
We have governmental groups.
And we know our communications are sufficiently good that we don't duplicate work.
I mean, we know what other people are doing.
The literature is very good.
We're in contact.
So we don't want to do something someone else is doing.
So the problem with duplication, that seems to
bother congressmen and so forth, it really doesn't exist.
We're much better off having a very loosely structured system, such as we have.
Once you have a very formalized large group and you're just a small pond somewhere down,
You get paid just as much for marching as you do for fighting.
And you have all these people above you and you try to write a paper and all these people are correcting your English and controlling what you do.
It's very difficult for people to ever be creative or to get something out.
The reason I've been productive over the years is in spite of the system, I've always felt that I was bypassing it or disobeying.
The letter of the rule should say, just get something done, getting proper clearances for publishing papers.
Try to get clearance, the thing will last for years.
I mean, these things go through channels and they get lost somewhere.
I wrote the first paper about economic use of manganese nodules and published it in the California Journal of Mines and Geology.
Well, this had to be sent to Washington for clearance, and it was two years.
I had to search for it and find it.
Finally, it came back, and I finally, but I mean, it just was hopeless to get something, something.
These idea procedures, clearance procedures, seemed to be very

useful and they're reasonable but the steps are such that you're you get to the point where a great many people rather than trying to fight the system just do nothing they just drift along so even now in my present position where I am right now you see I retired as the first of the year and I'm here as a guest of NOAA as an emeritus scientist
And this to me is a great feeling of freedom to me because now I can do just what I want to do.
And I'm here as a guest but as a retiree without salary and I'm my own person and I can write something and I'm not beholden.
I don't have this need to be concerned about being a government employee.
I can do things in my own right.
And this, of course, is a great pleasure being a university professor, which I am now.
I'm a visiting professor at two universities this year.
And so to me to go to university and be completely free and just not have to consult other people about what I'm doing and what I'm writing and where I'm publishing, this to me is really great.
It's really wonderful to have this freedom to do this.
Uh, describe your experiences in the USSR in, in 64 and in 66, speaking of relationships with governments.
Well, this, this to me was a very, uh, interesting experience.
And I, I've written a couple of papers about it and you may have seen them.
And, uh, many things are, are, you, you, you,

I've always regarded myself as sort of a liberal and I've always been sort of I guess friendly to Russians and Russian ideas and I came away with great mixed feelings of course I went there also with mixed feelings but I and I still
and not at all naive about the Russian system and the Soviets.
But I think I can detect their philosophy and their flaws.
I think, first of all, Churchill referred to Russia as being a paradox wrapped inside of an enigma.
Nothing could be further wrong.
the things in Russia are exactly what you would expect and everyone is goose-stepping they're all in everything is orderly and you can you can learn
To me, living in the U.S. is like a game of chess.
You can jump there, you can jump there, you can jump out of government.
If you don't like your boss, you can do this, you can go elsewhere.
If you have a job in Washington and you're not happy where you are, you just take a job elsewhere in the city and drive a different direction.
And you can't do this in Russia.
It's like a game of checkers.
And everywhere you're blocked, you're in a very strict hierarchy.
There's no service except the government service.
It's only one way up.
sort of a dead man's shoes development, and you have to wait for people to.
So you have this, even if you're not controlled by your superiors and by their thoughts, you're in a system where any advancement involves these people.
So even if it's not an overt control of your work, you're very highly controlled, and this is a very sterile sort of life.

and it's the idea of the Soviet Union being advanced technologically or socially is rather ridiculous they're very Victorian in all their mores and their science too I mean their ideas are it's I just reviewed a paper here
for Sea Frontiers of this book called The World Rift System or something like that.
This book, they still don't believe in continental drift.
I mean, it's rather, it's archaic.
Of course, it's a book published a couple years ago, but even so, they're just so far behind the times in their notions and ideas that they just really aren't with the modern world.
Well, the...
You must give them credit for what they've done, of course.
But you wonder how they do it.
And I have the feeling that they do it more or less the way we did things in the Army.
If you send two men to do a job and they can't do it, you send four.
If four can't do it, you send eight.
So it's a very massive sort of pondering approach to solutions of projects.
But it's not a very...
It's a very stifling system.
Why specifically did you go to the Soviet Union in 64 and 66?
Why did I go?
Well, I guess the first time I went, I was invited to be on the delegation of
At that time, we had set up these exchanges, of course, and I was invited to participate as a member of that delegation, as the marine geologist geophysicist.
And so I was very anxious to see the Soviet Union, and I thought I could do a useful job.
And so I accepted and was on this team.
This is one of the advantages of being in Washington, DC.
These nice things happen to you when you're in Washington, which never happened to you when you're out in the field.
Things like this are organized in Washington.
And if you're there, you're likely to be invited.
But if you're somewhere else, like down in Miami, your chances of being invited to participate are minimal.
And I returned in 66 to the Second International Oceanographic Congress.

Of course, I was extremely interested in developments in the Soviet Union, just as a scientific and cultural problem to really see how a system which, you know, seems to be beautifully organized, they have all the very simple correct wiring diagrams and so forth,
why it didn't work.
I was interested in knowing why it didn't work.

Because it would appear to be a model of efficiency, you know, but it's a... And you go there and you'll find out, soon realize that the flaws in the system, the fact that they're too tightly coupled.
How did meteorites fit into your career?
Well, I...
As I explained in the beginning, an interest of mine was in astronomy.
And I went to University of Illinois, even with the idea of possibly majoring in astronomy.
But I was not inspired by the particular professor there, Professor Baker, the one man astronomy department.
So I took some course in astronomy, but I didn't go beyond that.
But I did retain this interest in
in astronomy and in the moon as a geological object, because we could see the features on the moon.
And I, in fact, when I submitted an idea for a PhD thesis, I submitted the idea that I should try to interpret the lunar surface.
And this proposal of mine was declined by the University of Illinois.
Well, I'd like to say because they told me, I guess rather facetiously, that there's no way of checking my field work.

Actually, there was no professor there who was interested in sort of sponsoring this work that I could work under, and so I worked on these deep-sea clays instead, but I did have this interest, and when I was in the Air Force, I was involved in photo mapping, so I became very interested in this aspect of
remote sensing, and of course we see more or less an aerial map of the moon.

So I, and I was aware as a student in Illinois of the structure at Ketlin, which was then called a cryptovolcanic structure caused by some hidden volcanic explosion, and I visited during World War II on

I had occasion to fly around in connection with training flights, and one time with transferring aircraft, I would stop close by and get out to this quarry and study it, and had these features we call shatter cones, which, and I reasoned that, well, this is one of those ideas that come to you ahead of time, and you go to the field to check it.
I thought the orientation of the shatter cone should reveal what the force came from above or from below, once you turn the rocks to their
pre-event position to a horizontal position.
And this concept was sort of really confirmed by this visit.
I saw that the rocks, the shatter cones pointed upward and therefore the force came from above, therefore it was likely caused by a cosmic impact and not by a force from below as from volcanism.
So I then wrote this paper on this orientation of shatter cones and
pointed out this must be a meteorite impact feature.
And then I more or less forgot about this field, not entirely because I, when I was with ONR, I was, I didn't want to just be an administrator entirely.

So I would, when I went to Germany, I also visited the Steinhain Basin and the Reese Basin, which were two examples of this type of impact feature, which we now know known to be, but were thought to be volcanic.
And so I always took advantage of these travels to do some geology.
As I've done on all my oceanography trips, I've always tried to do some land geology at various remote parts of the world.
And so I wrote this paper on these shatter cones and the probable impact origin of these features in Germany.
And along

In 58 or 56 I guess the Sputnik thing came along and this was a big event of course scientifically and initiation of the space program so I at that time I visited about 58 I guess I visited I was invited down to the McDonald Observatory by Gerard Kuiper in Texas
with Gene Schumacher and two other people and we were, Gene Schumacher became head of the Astrogeology program for the USGS.
But we were looking at the moon through the telescope and I told him I thought I knew where there was a lunar crater on the earth.
At least the counterpart.
This was the Sierra Madera impact structure and had a certain structural style.
And so we visited one day during the day because it had clouded over and we couldn't observe at night.
And sure enough, this was a shatter cone structure.
So this was very important, I think, in triggering the search for more of these features and for
This has resulted in much work by the U.S.
Logical Survey looking at these sites, which are, I guess, demonstrated now to be the lunar counterparts of lunar craters.
They are terrestrial counterparts of lunar craters.
Now, what about international cooperation on oceanographic voyages?
I'm thinking particularly about MIDPAC and the Indian Ocean experience.
How did you feel about this?
What were your experiences on these voyages?
Well, MIPAC, I guess, was not an international cooperation.
This was between Scripps and the Navy.
The international cooperation, I guess the first event there was the Indian Ocean, the International Indian Ocean Expedition.
I think it was a good thing to
I think oceanography acted as sort of the focal point for bringing countries together, particularly from behind the Iron Curtain.
I think in the Indian Ocean Expedition, countries all really worked more or less separately and used this as a...
The first of these things, of course, was the Second International Geophysical Year in 1958.

And this was a mechanism of going to the highest levels of government, even the Congress, and getting funding because you had something which was big enough for them to, or a mission which was large enough for them to fund as a separate entity.
And it was not a very efficient way of doing scientific work.
it was useful in using science as a platform or as a focal point for bringing countries together socially and economically in other ways.
But I think for the amount of money spent, you'd be better off to have not to do it as international projects, but just simply as national projects because, again, these

if you go back to the Russian analogy of a large ship and all these programs 60, 80 scientists on the ship all with different programs doing marine biology and this and that and other things they really don't this is not a very efficient way of doing doing scientific work the most efficient ships in the world doing scientific work for the least amount of money have been ships like the Lamont ship the uh
which did purely geophysics all around the world.
This ship has been uniquely productive.
Much more important work than these huge floating hotels.
And the same way the international work is useful for doing certain things, but it's not a very productive way or efficient way of getting scientific results.
Would you say the same about mid-pack?
Well, the Midpac expedition was not in its level.
All involved was two other small ships, one Navy ship, one Scripps ship.
And I was the chief scientist for the Navy group of scientists, and Roger Bell was the chief scientist for the Scripps ship.
And I guess the importance of Midpac is that it
it got Scripps away from coastal oceanography.
It got them going doing deep sea.
It was the first of their series of deep sea expeditions, which went on, still going on today.
The Navy made this one effort to do it, and we had the...
But then the Navy folded up the program.
They wouldn't really give us any more support to do more or less deep sea work, except on this sort of, you know, continuing basis, where Scripps went on to...
to doing this work, I identified them.
We got some very good results.
I mean, the main result was discovering the Mid-Pacific Mountains and the geos and the age of the Mid-Pacific Mountains.
So, this was the opening wedge that got Scripps started in deep-sea oceanography, but it was abortive as far as the Navy is concerned, getting the Navy involved in deep-sea oceanography.
Your early work on minerals in the sea, one of the things that you're rightly well known for, what do you look upon the sea as a potential producer of minerals for man?
Well, the sea is somewhat disappointing.
There are
several aspects of the sea.
One, of course, are the continental shelves and slopes, which are simply extensions of the land.
And what you have on land will occur offshore, but it will be more difficult and expensive to get at.
The important item here, of course, is the hydrocarbons.
And since hydrocarbons tend to occur in sedimentary basins,
And in young sedimentary basins, these tend to be at margins of continents.
So the marginal regions may be very productive.
Now we're getting about, I think, somewhere between 15 to 20% of our oil from offshore.
This is bound to increase.
But when we say offshore, we're including things like Lake Maracaibo and so forth, which are really not

you know not open shelf as far as deep-sea concerned the only it must think in terms of the hydrosphere the water itself and the of course we get now we get salt magnesium bromine from seawater and also iodine from

ocean plants uh but the the the water is uniform over the world and although it's nice having these standpoint of process of processing to have these these ions in solution they're very the the dilution is so low and so constant

people talk for example of the ocean containing a hundred million dollars worth of gold per cubic mile an exaggeration but even if it's not a cubic mile of water is an enormous amount of material the total hydrocarbons oil produced over the years is only about one cubic mile and so
Even a cubic mile of granite contains $500 million worth of five times as much gold as a cubic mile of seawater.
But no one would think of mining just granite.
You have to high-grade it.
You have to look for the veins.
Well, in the ocean water, we have no veins.
No high-grade deposits of these things.
It's all uniform.
Regarding the ocean floor, there are, first you think in terms of the sediments, then more or less the ocean crust itself.

now the sediments we have the the sedimentary orthogenic deposits like the manganese nodules and phosphorite nodules these are not ores today but one one day presumably will be and uh and the ocean crust itself the ocean crust itself is it's too bad that the oceans were
generated the way they were because the ocean crust is just pure tholiatic basalt, ocean tholiite.
This is remarkably uniform material and it's like trying to look for mineral deposits in Hawaii or Iceland.
It's not a very good territory for looking for mineral deposits because to have mineral deposits you must have metamorphism and

you'd rather have old terrain rather than young terrain you'd rather have it reprocessed geologically many times to develop veins and that sort of thing so the ocean is way overrated as a storehouse of minerals it's also way overrated as a storehouse as a cornucopia of food and it's not going to supply the expanding populations at all we really can't look to the ocean to do this this is rather a
a sad story of marine geology, but that's, those are the facts.
It's not very optimistic.
I'm sure we can solve the legal hassles involved in recovering manganese nodules, and I'm sure that one day they will be economic, will become ours.

but I'm not so optimistic as some people are about them I think it'll be some years before they do become economic today the only thing we are recovering from the only mineral resource if we use that word for recovering from the deep ocean floor or from seamounts is precious coral this is the only resource we have now from the deep ocean which is being recovered economically so
really the mineral potential in the oceans is somewhat overrated.
Of course, we do have this problem of the hydrothermal deposits, which we're finding in mid-ocean rifts associated with aqueous solutions, which may be economic.
And we do also have the Red Sea situation of

red sea brines and their associated deposits but this is this is a very unique environment we can't expect to find these brines elsewhere because it involves the rising of hot water solutions through giant salt deposits
